text: Hey <@U025LU739QD>! I did the same thing as Amanda. I let a few clients know I wanted to transition to a full-time role by asking for references, and got a competing offer from an existing client.  It’s a big challenge transitioning from creator/contributor to my new role of Content Marketing Manager.  (Wound up in a management job in tech that I never even applied or interviewed for!) There are a lot of gaps that pop up when you fulfil a strategy vs. creating the strategy; for me, many of those gaps lie in creating processes more than technical or creative know-how. I think what worked for me initially when job hunting was providing additionally strategic insight/input into the content I produced, which let clients know I could do more than produce. I still have gaps to fill, and I’m going to do an MSc in Digital Marketing (a good option for me but not necessarily for everyone) that’s really well built for my particular skill gap and schedule.

text: Like Amanda and Nikki, I also made this transition with an existing client. I didn't seek it out, but he needed someone to fill the role and thought I could do it best out of his existing freelancers. It's a startup, and my responsibilities keep on growing. I now have a VP role and handle content ops and project management while contributing to sales and even some copywriting still as well. It's been fun! It helps that he knew upfront I would be learning as I went, but we've always worked well together.

elements.text: Like Amanda and Nikki, I also made this transition with an existing client. I didn't seek it out, but he needed someone to fill the role and thought I could do it best out of his existing freelancers. It's a startup, and my responsibilities keep on growing. I now have a VP role and handle content ops and project management while contributing to sales and even some copywriting still as well. It's been fun! It helps that he knew upfront I would be learning as I went, but we've always worked well together.

text: The biggest challenge has probably been that I wasn't stepping into an established role with established systems. I've been making it up as I go along. Nothing terrible has come of that :slightly_smiling_face: but I'm not just _learning_ as I go—I'm _building_ as I go.

elements.text: The biggest challenge has probably been that I wasn't stepping into an established role with established systems. I've been making it up as I go along. Nothing terrible has come of that

text: do we have any marketing analytics folks here? and would you be willing to share your salary (in a DM, not publicly)?

elements.text: do we have any marketing analytics folks here? and would you be willing to share your salary (in a DM, not publicly)?

text: I've worked with clients to hire freelance writers, onboard and manage those writers, and delegate content that they had already planned. It was a nice stepping stone. They ended up offering me a full-time role, which I turned down and later a part-time role in the same position, which I also turned down. I'm happier as a freelancer, but it is possible to transition with a current client pretty smoothly!
